text: expectations are high for Barack Obama's
inaugural address for the man to match
the moment he won the presidency partly
on his speaking ability and he intends
to govern using his powers of persuasion
my job is to be so persuasive today you
all decide yourselves you know what I've
got to vote for that guy for President
of the United States mr. Obama's
inauguration will mark the first
transition of power in this country
since 9/11 change has come to America
the torch has been passed to a new
generation of Americans Ted Sorensen who
was John Kennedy's speech writer says
mr. Obama has to think globally that
inaugural address is going to define his
presidency in the eyes of the rest of
the world as an aside the legendary
speechwriter had a quick observation
about mr. Obama's style if I were to
fault him I would say that occasionally
his sentences and words are not always
short be that as it may mr. Obama has to
be something of an oratorical acrobat a
realist but also an optimist Ted Widmer
is a former speechwriter for President
Clinton he doesn't want to create the
feeling that he will magically solve all
these pretty difficult problems right
away at the same time he does want to
create the feeling that the problems are
ultimately solvable he can use his
oratory to great effect like after he
lost New Hampshire and together we will
begin the next great chapter in the
American story with three words that
will ring from coast to coast from sea
to shining sea yes we can thank you to a
stroke that would become his rallying
cry the question is whether he can
translate those campaign skills into
governing there is some truth to the
axiom that you can campaign in poetry
but you have to govern in
crows if we act with the urgency and
seriousness that this moment requires I
know that we can do it again
the inaugural address is something unto
itself
neither campaigning nor governing an
inaugural address is not a campaign
speech it's not a State of the Union
address there's no laundry list of
specific legislative proposals if mr.
Obama has any doubt about what's at
stake he was reminded recently by an
unlikely adviser during a visit to the
Lincoln Memorial and then we go and look
at the Lincoln second inaugural which is
on the other wall and Sasha looks up and
she says boy that's a long speech do you
have to give one of those I said
actually that one's pretty short mine
may even be a little longer
at which point then Malia turns to me
and says first african-american
president better be good
